subject: RE: [junit] RE: [TDD] Re: Test-first in less iterative organizations
msgSnippet: ... I am working exactly in the same way :) I d love to see a hint for not yet implemented tests. Bernd
messageBody:
> I tend to prefer to add a test case with no tests (you get an
> Assert: no
> tests found in testcase: xxx) or add a test method which fails with a
> message "Not implemented!".
>
> This way at least I'm reminded every time I run the test
> suite. I can't do
> paper lists as I usually lose or damage them somehow, and my
> mental list
> can easily become lost ;)
>
> I do realise though that this means I do have to mentally
> block out the red
> tests/suites that are just those not implemented, from those that are
> failing.
>
> Maybe JUnit could be enhanced to have Amber tests for these
> situations?
>
> Green: Test passes
> Amber: Test fails as it isn't implemented
> Red: test fails
>
> What do people think?

I am working exactly in the same way :)

I'd love to see a hint for "not yet implemented" tests.

Bernd


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Ilja Preuss [mailto:preuss@...]
> Sent: 07 February 2003 14:03
> To: testdrivendevelopment@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: AW: [TDD] Re: Test-first in less iterative organizations
>
>
> Ron Jeffries wrote:
>
> > However, unlike some other practitioners, I almost never
> write down any
> > notes about tests I want to remember for possible implementation.
> > I have no
> > physical scratchpad, and generally do not perceive myself
> to be working
> > through some list. Surely there is some of that but my
> perception is much
> > more that once one test is done, the next becomes obvious.
> >
> > It's possible that I have more of a list in my head than I'm
> > aware of. It's
> > also possible that with a century of experience and a
> highly intuitive and
> > interrupt-driven style of thinking, things just "come" to
> me. Still, I
> > perceive nothing very "scratchpad" about the way I think,
> and I use no
> > physical forward-looking list at all.
>
> That aligns with my experience - I typically have some rough
> ideas about
> what I probably will need to test, but I don't write them
> down. It's mainly
> the state of the production code which motivates my next test, not a
> predetermined list.
>
> I have the suspicion that this is very individual; there is a
> programmer I
> much like to pair with because of her very different way of thinking -
> possibly having a test list written down could smooth pairing
> sessions here.
>
> Regards, Ilja
>
